currentWeek.title: Don't Turn The Bass Down (with Azahriah)
currentWeek.description:
Single from L’Entourloop “Don’t Turn the Bass Down,” featuring Hungarian songwriter and YouTuber Azahriah. 
Inspired by reggae legends, L’Entourloop pays homage to reggae, dancehall, and hip-hop culture.

archive.title: Egyptian Reggae / Carnaval De Jujuy
archive.description: Cumbia is a language, not a genre. On one side, Pancho Acosta takes Jonathan Richman's catchy 'Egyptian Reggae' and turns it into a fun, upbeat cumbia track with a lively beat and lots of accordion flair. Flip it over, and Austin's Money Chicha puts their own spin on Acosta's 'Carnaval de Jujuy', with electric guitars and deep basslines that make you want to move.

archive.title: Ayo Ke Disco: Boogie, Pop & Funk from the South China Sea (1974-88)
archive.description: For Ayo Ke Disco (meaning ‘Let’s go to the disco’ in Indonesian), 10 rare tracks of disco-funk, psychedelic funk, synth, city pop, and Hindustani-Arabic rhythms were painstakingly licensed from local labels – forming a snapshot of the vibrant discotheques and live scenes across Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong and the Philippines.

archive.title: Al Hadaoui
archive.description: This album is pure sonic dynamite! Pulled together by the essential Habibi Funk label, this compiles the potent 1970s recordings of Attarazat Addahabia, that gritty Casablanca hotel band, fronted by the unmistakable voice of Faradjallah. You can almost feel the raw energy captured, likely on minimal equipment back in the day. It’s a hypnotic brew across the tracks, blending deep traditional Moroccan sounds – you hear those Gnawa vibes loud and clear – with seriously fuzzy psych guitar riffs, swirling, beautifully raw organ lines, and relentless, driving funk rhythms that just lock you in. Forget polished studio perfection; this is the sound of a working band absolutely cooking, miles away from glossy disco, dripping with psych-rock intensity mixed with utterly infectious North African funk grooves. It's a crucial document of raw Moroccan musical innovation from the era, a truly essential find rescued from obscurity!

archive.title: sunflower girl/ hippie hindustani
archive.embed: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/9qA4wD9T9EU?si=Zxjr8Clg_QhmRetL" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>
archive.description: Arun Amin and Bonnie Remedios' songs "Sunflower Girl" and "Hippie Hindustan" are rare examples of Indian psychedelic music from the early 1970s, blending folk and rock elements with traditional Indian instrumentation. Their work, though obscure, is valued by collectors and discussed in online communities, reflecting a niche but important part of musical history.

archive.title: EVOLUTION
archive.artist: Jeff Mills, Jean-Phi Dary, Prabhu Edouard
archive.description: Tomorrow Comes The Harvest project started with late Tony Allen, one of the originators of AfroBeat and Jeff Mills to get together to create an improvisational type of performance. The idea was to not pre-prepare or to preplan anything, but just to play in the moment spontaneously and to reach for the same understanding musically. Jean-Phi Dary had been worked with Tony Allen for a long time, naturally joined the unit. After an untimely passing of Tony in 2020, they thought that maybe a good idea to continue with the project and to consider it in a much more broader respect other than just three main musicians that may be, it's interesting to make it open, to be able to invite other musicians in for certain concerts. They decided to invite Prabhu Edouard, who already had an experience of working with Jeff for classical concerts in France. The album was recorded live at Bozar in Brussels, Belgium in 2022.

archive.title: Blue Latin
archive.description: Blue Latin takes classic jazz and shakes it up with Afro-Cuban, Brazilian, and Latin-jazz vibes — all wrapped in Frisina's signature danceable style. It's the perfect soundtrack for a packed dance floor or a solo groove session at home. With standout tracks like the rework of João Donato's Naquela Base and the meditative, African-inspired Incanto, this album brings jazz right into the now.

archive.title: Ten Ragas to a Disco Beat
archive.description: 'Ten Ragas to a Disco Beat' is a 1982 album by Indian musician Charanjit Singh that uniquely blends traditional Indian ragas with electronic disco music. Utilizing instruments like the Roland TB-303 bass synthesizer, TR-808 drum machine, and Jupiter-8 synthesizer, Singh crafted a sound that many consider a precursor to acid house music, predating the genre's rise in the late 1980s. Initially overlooked, the album gained recognition in the 21st century for its innovative fusion of classical Indian music and electronic dance rhythms.

archive.title: Eastern Sounds
archive.description: Eastern Sounds is a studio album by the jazz multi-instrumentalist and composer Yusef Lateef. It was released in April 1962 through Prestige Records. This groundbreaking album reflects Lateef's exploration of Eastern musical traditions, combining them with Western jazz idioms to create a unique sonic landscape. His innovative approach to composition and instrumentation established him as one of the pioneers in world music fusion, decades before the term was widely used.
